Provide comprehensive HIV prevention options: 
- STI screening and treatment (syndromic and syphilis)
- Condom promotion
- Risk reduction counselling
- PrEP with emphasis on adherence
- Emphasize importance of follow-up ANC contact visits

Profile.Label: LMP known?
Profile.Info icon: LMP = first day of Last Menstrual Period. If the exact date is unknown, but the period of the month is known, use day 5 for beginning of the month, day 15 for middle of the month and day 25 for end of the month. If completely unknown, select "No" and calculate GA from ultrasound (or SFH or abdominal palpation as a last resort).
Profile.Name: lmp_known
Profile.Description: Whether woman's LMP date is known or not.
Profile.OpenMRS entity: Concept - Date of last menstrual period unknown

Profile.Label: Specify date
Profile.Name: lmp
Profile.Description: The woman's Last Menstrual Period (LMP) date. This is defined as the first day of her most recent period.
Profile.Constraint(s): <= {today} and can't be an LMP that makes the woman more than 40 weeks GA (i.e. <= 40 weeks GA).
Profile.OpenMRS entity: Concept - Date of last menstrual period

Profile.Label: NA
Profile.Name: lmp_edd
Profile.Description: Expected Date of Delivery (EDD) calculated from LMP.
Profile.Calculation: {lmp} + 7 days + 9 calendar months (e.g. LMP is 9 April 2018, then EDD would be 16 January 2019)

Profile.Label: NA
Profile.Name: lmp_gest_age
Profile.Description: Gestational age (GA) calculated from LMP.
Profile.Calculation: (today's date - {lmp}) / 7, shown in weeks and days

Profile.Label: GA from SFH or palpation - wks
Profile.Info icon:
Gestational age (GA) from Symphysis Fundal Height (SFH) or abdominal palpation

If LMP is unknown and ultrasound wasn't done or it wasn't done early (before 24 weeks), then assess GA based on Symphysis Fundal Height (SFH) or abdominal palpation. Compare this GA against ultrasound GA (if done).
Profile.Name: sfh_gest_age
Profile.Description: If LMP is unknown and either ultrasound wasn't done or it wasn't done early enough, then show the option for health worker to enter GA in weeks based on Symphysis Fundal Height (SFH) or abdominal palpation.

Profile.Label: NA
Profile.Name: sfh_edd
Profile.Description: EDD calculated from SFH GA.

Profile.Label: Select preferred gestational age:
Profile.Info icon: If the difference between GA from LMP and early ultrasound is one week or less, then use GA from LMP. If the difference is more than 7 days, use the early ultrasound GA. If ultrasound was done late, use GA from LMP. Between late ultrasound and SFH or abdominal palpation, use your best judgment to select GA.
Profile.Name: select_gest_age_edd
Profile.Description: If GA and EDD are calculated from different methods (LMP, ultrasound, SFH/abdominal palpation), then the health worker should select which to use.
Profile.Default?:
LMP and ultrasound done:

1) Early ultrasound done {ultrasound_gest_age_wks} < 24: If the difference between {lmp_edd} and {ultrasound_edd} is <= 7 days, then default to {lmp_edd}. If the difference is > 7 days, default to {ultrasound_edd}.

2) Early ultrasound not done {ultrasound_gest_age_wks} >= 24: Default to {lmp_edd}.

Ultrasound and SFH/abdominal palpation: No default selected.
Profile.OpenMRS entity: Concept - Method of gestational age determination

Profile.Name: gdm_risk
Profile.Description:
The woman is considered at risk for GDM if she has any of the following risk factors: 
- BMI of 30 kg/m2 or more
- Previous GDM
- Previous macrosomia 
- Glycosuria on dipstick testing is ++ or above on one occasion OR + on two or more occasions)
Profile.Calculation: if(({bmi} >= 30) OR ({prev_preg_comps} = 'Gestational Diabetes' or 'Macrosomia') OR ({urine_glucose} = '++', '+++', or '++++') OR ({urine_glucose} = '+' more than once), 1, 0)

Profile.Label: WOMAN'S BEHAVIOUR
Profile.Info icon: "BEHAVIOUR" for short

Profile.Label: Daily caffeine intake
Profile.Info icon:
Pregnant women should not consume more than 300 mg of caffeine per day. Each of the following represents 300 mg of caffeine.

- 2 cups (200 ml) of filtered or commercially brewed coffee 
- 2 small cups (50 ml) of espresso
- 3 cups (300 ml) of instant coffee
- 48 pieces (squares) of chocolate

Please indicate if the woman consumes more than these amounts per day.
Profile.Name: caffeine_intake
Profile.Description: Assesses whether the woman consumes more than 300 mg of caffeine per day.
Profile.Constraint(s): Cannot select "None" with any other option.

Profile.Choices: More than 2 cups (200 ml) of filtered or commercially brewed coffee
Profile.OpenMRS entity: Concept - More than 2 cups (200ml) of filtered or commercially brewed coffee

Profile.Choices: More than 2 small cups (50 ml) of espresso
Profile.OpenMRS entity: Concept - More than 2 small cups (50 ml) of espresso

Profile.Choices: More than 3 cups (300 ml) of instant coffee
Profile.OpenMRS entity: Concept - More than 3 cups (300ml) of instant coffee
Concept - More than 48 pieces (squares) of chocolate

Profile.Label: Caffeine reduction counseling
Profile.Info icon:
Lowering daily caffeine intake during pregnancy is recommended to reduce the risk of pregnancy loss and low-birth-weight neonates.

This includes any product, beverage or food containing caffeine (e.g. brewed coffee, tea, cola-type soft drinks, caffeinated energy drinks, chocolate, caffeine tablets). Caffeine-containing teas (black tea and green tea) and soft drinks (colas and iced tea) usually contain less than 50 mg per 250 ml serving.
Profile.Relevance: (caffeine_intake} = More than 2 cups (200ml) of filtered or commercially brewed coffee; More than 2 small cups (50 ml) of espresso; More than 3 cups (300ml) of instant coffee; More than 48 pieces (squares) of chocolate

Profile.Description: Counseling on lowering caffeine intake.

S&F.Label: PREVIOUSLY REPORTED BEHAVIOUR
S&F.Info icon: "PREVIOUS BEHAVIOUR" for short

S&F.Label: Which of the following behaviours persist?
S&F.Info icon:
These behaviours were reported in the previous contact. Select the ones that are still occurring or select "None".

High caffeine intake info icon:
High caffeine intake means consuming more than 300 mg of caffeine per day. Each of the following represents 300 mg of caffeine:
- 2 cups (200ml) of filtered or commercially brewed coffee 
- 2 small cups (50 ml) of espresso
- 3 cups (300ml) of instant coffee
- 48 pieces (squares) of chocolate

Please indicate if the woman consumes more than these amounts per day.
S&F.Relevance:
After a behaviour was reported in first contact in Profile tab.

"High caffeine intake" if (caffeine_intake} = "More than 2 cups (200ml) of filtered or commercially brewed coffee" OR "More than 2 small cups (50 ml) of espresso" OR "More than 3 cups (300ml) of instant coffee" OR "More than 48 pieces (squares) of chocolate"

"Current tobacco use or recently quit" if {tobacco_user} = "Yes" OR "Recently quit"

"Exposure to second-hand smoke in the home" if {shs_exposure} = "Yes"

"No condom use during sex" if {condom_use} = "No"

"Alcohol or substance use" if {alcohol_substance_use} = "Alcohol" OR "Marijuana" OR "Cocaine" OR "Crack" OR "Injectable drugs" OR "Other (specify)"
S&F.Name: behaviour_persist
S&F.Description: Select which of the following behaviours persist after being reported during last contact.
S&F.Constraint(s): Cannot select "None" with any other answer choice.
S&F.OpenMRS entity: Concept - Persistent behaviors after last contact

S&F.Choices: Current tobacco use or recently quit
Exposure to second-hand smoke in the home

S&F.OpenMRS entity: Concept - No condom use during sex

S&F.Label: Caffeine reduction counseling
S&F.Info icon:
Lowering daily caffeine intake during pregnancy is recommended to reduce the risk of pregnancy loss and low-birth-weight neonates.

This includes any product, beverage or food containing caffeine (e.g. brewed coffee, tea, cola-type soft drinks, caffeinated energy drinks, chocolate, caffeine tablets). Caffeine-containing teas (black tea and green tea) and soft drinks (colas and iced tea) usually contain less than 50 mg per 250 ml serving.
S&F.Name: NA
S&F.Description: Note displaying that the woman is consuming too much caffeine and counseling should be given to reduce intake.

S&F.Label: Tobacco cessation counseling
S&F.Info icon: Healthcare providers should routinely offer advice and psycho-social interventions for tobacco cessation to all pregnant women who are either current tobacco users or recent tobacco quitters.
S&F.Name: NA
S&F.Description: Note displaying that the woman consumes tobacco products and tobacco cessation counseling should be given.

S&F.Label: Second-hand smoke counseling
S&F.Info icon: Provide pregnant women, their partners and other household members with advice and information about the risks of second-hand smoke (SHS) exposure from all forms of smoked tobacco, as well as strategies to reduce SHS in the home.
S&F.Relevance: {behaviour_persist} = "Exposure to second-hand smoke in the home"
S&F.Name: NA
S&F.Description: Note displaying that the woman is exposed to secondhand smoke and counseling should be given.

S&F.Label: Condom counseling
S&F.Info icon: Advise to use condoms to prevent Zika, HIV and other STIs. If necessary, re-assure it is ok to continue to have sex during pregnancy.
S&F.Name: NA
S&F.Description: Note displaying that woman is not using condoms to prevent Zika or STIs and counseling should be given.

S&F.Label: Alcohol / substance use counseling
S&F.Info icon: Healthcare providers should at the earliest opportunity advise pregnant women dependent on alcohol or drugs to cease their alcohol or drug use and offer, or refer them to, detoxification services under medical supervision, where necessary and applicable.
S&F.Name: NA
S&F.Description: Note displaying that woman is consuming alcohol or other substances and should be counseled on cessation and detoxification services.

S&F.Label: Pharmacological treatments for nausea and vomiting counseling
S&F.Info icon: Pharmacological treatments for nausea and vomiting, such as doxylamine and metoclopramide, should be reserved for those pregnant women experiencing distressing symptoms that are not relieved by non-pharmacological options, under the supervision of a medical doctor.
S&F.Name: NA
S&F.Description: Counseling for the symptom "Nausea and vomiting" not relieved.

S&F.Label: Antacid preparations to relieve heartburn counseling
S&F.Info icon: Antacid preparations can be offered to women with troublesome symptoms that are not relieved by lifestyle modification. Magnesium carbonate and aluminium hydroxide preparations are probably unlikely to cause harm in recommended dosages.
S&F.Name: NA
S&F.Description: Counseling for the symptom "Heartburn" not relieved.

S&F.Label: Magnesium and calcium to relieve leg cramps counseling
S&F.Info icon: If leg cramps are not relieved with non-pharma measures, then give 300–360 mg magnesium per day in two or three divided doses; give calcium 1 g twice daily for two weeks.
S&F.Name: NA
S&F.Description: Counseling for the symptom "Leg cramps" not relieved.

S&F.Label: Wheat bran or other fiber supplements to relieve constipation counseling
S&F.Info icon: Wheat bran or other fiber supplements can be used to relieve constipation, if dietary modifications are not enough, and if they are available and appropriate.
S&F.Name: NA
S&F.Description: Counseling for the symptom "Constipation" not relieved.

S&F.Label: Regular exercise, physiotherapy, support belts and acupuncture to relieve low back and pelvic pain counseling
S&F.Info icon: Regular exercise throughout pregnancy is recommended to prevent low back and pelvic pain. There are a number of different treatment options that can be used, such as physiotherapy, support belts and acupuncture, based on a woman’s preferences and available options.
S&F.Relevance: {phys_symptoms_persist} = "Low back pain" OR "Pelvic pain" AND selected({other_sym_lbpp}, "None")
S&F.Name: NA
S&F.Description: Counseling for the symptom "Low back and pelvic pain".

S&F.Label: Please investigate any possible complications or onset of labour, related to low back and pelvic pain
S&F.Relevance: selected({other_sym_lbpp}, "Contractions" OR "Extreme pelvic pain, can't walk (symphysis pubis dysfunction)")
S&F.Name: NA
S&F.Description: Counseling for additional symptoms of "Low back and pelvic pain".

S&F.Info icon: Woman has dysuria. Please investigate urinary tract infection and treat if positive.
S&F.Name: NA
S&F.Description: Note displaying that woman's symptoms identified the need for a urine test.

S&F.Label: Non-pharmacological options for varicose veins and oedema counseling
S&F.Info icon: Non-pharmacological options, such as compression stockings, leg elevation and water immersion, can be used for the management of varicose veins and oedema in pregnancy, based on a woman’s preferences and available options.
S&F.Name: NA
S&F.Description: Counseling for the symptom "Varicose veins or oedema".

S&F.Label: Non-pharma measures to relieve nausea and vomiting counseling
S&F.Info icon: Ginger, chamomile, vitamin B6 and/or acupuncture are recommended for the relief of nausea in early pregnancy, based on a woman’s preferences and available options. Women should be informed that symptoms of nausea and vomiting usually resolve in the second half of pregnancy.

S&F.Label: Diet and lifestyle changes to prevent and relieve heartburn counseling
S&F.Info icon: Advice on diet and lifestyle is recommended to prevent and relieve heartburn in pregnancy. Antacid preparations can be offered to women with troublesome symptoms that are not relieved by lifestyle modification.

S&F.Label: Non-pharmacological treatment for the relief of leg cramps counseling
S&F.Info icon: Non-pharmacological therapies, including muscle stretching, relaxation, heat therapy, dorsiflexion of the foot, and massage can be used for the relief of leg cramps in pregnancy.

S&F.Label: Dietary modifications to relieve constipation counseling

S&F.Label: Regular exercise, physiotherapy, support belts and acupuncture to relieve low back and pelvic pain counseling
S&F.Info icon: Regular exercise throughout pregnancy is recommended to prevent low back and pelvic pain. There are a number of different treatment options that can be used, such as physiotherapy, support belts and acupuncture, based on a woman’s preferences and available options.

PE.Label: Height (cm)
PE.Name: height
PE.Description: The woman's height in centimetres.

PE.Label: Pre-gestational weight (kg)
PE.Name: pregest_weight
PE.Description: The woman's pre-gestational weight in kilograms. Check unknown (see next row) if not known.
PE.Required: Either {pregest_weight} must be answered or {pregest_weight_uknown} must be checked, but not both.

PE.Label: [Unknown checkbox inline with {pregest_weight}]
PE.Name: pregest_weight_unknown
PE.Description: Check this box if the woman's pre-gestational weight is unknown.
PE.Required: Either {pregest_weight} must be answered or {pregest_weight_uknown} must be checked, but not both.

PE.Label: Current weight (kg)
PE.Name: current_weight
PE.Description: The woman's current weight in kilograms.

PE.Label: NA
PE.Name: first_weight
PE.Description: This is a calculated field for purposes of making weight calculations simpler. It fixes which weight to use as pre-gestational weight.

PE.Label: NA
PE.Name: bmi
PE.Description: Body mass index (BMI) is calculated by taking weight in kg divided by the squared height in meters, i.e., kg/m^2.

PE.Label: NA
PE.Name: gdm_risk
PE.Description:
The woman is considered at risk for GDM if she has any of the following risk factors: 
- BMI of 30 kg/m2 or more
- Previous GDM
- Previous macrosomia 
- Glycosuria on dipstick testing is ++ or above on one occasion OR + on two or more occasions)
PE.Calculation: if(({bmi} >= 30) OR ({prev_preg_comps} = 'Gestational Diabetes' or 'Macrosomia') OR ({urine_glucose} = '++', '+++', or '++++') OR ({urine_glucose} = '+' more than once), 1, 0)
PE.OpenMRS entity: Concept - At risk for gestational diabetes

PE.Label: NA
PE.Name: weight_cat
PE.Description: Weight category is calculated from BMI.
PE.Calculation: if({bmi} < 18.5, "Underweight", if({bmi} >= 18.5 and {bmi} < 25, "Normal Weight", if({bmi} >= 25 and {bmi} < 30, "Overweight")), "Obese")

PE.Label: NA
PE.Name: exp_weight_gain
PE.Description: Expected weight gain during pregnancy is based on the woman's weight category.

PE.Label: NA
PE.Name: weight_gain
PE.Description: Average weight gain per week since last contact (in kg). This would only display starting at the 2nd contact.
PE.Calculation: ({current_weight} [from this contact] - {current_weight} [from most recent contact]) / (({today} - {last contact date}) / 7)

PE.Label: NA
PE.Name: tot_weight_gain
PE.Description: Total weight gain in pregnancy so far (in kg).

PE.Label:
Body mass index (BMI) = {bmi}

Woman is {weight_cat}. Weight gain during pregnancy should be {exp_weight_gain} kg.
PE.Name: NA
PE.Description: Note displaying the woman's BMI, her weight category, and how much weight she should put on during pregnancy for her weight category.

PE.Label:
Average weight gain per week since last contact: {weight_gain} kg

Total weight gain in pregnancy so far: {tot_weight_gain} kg
PE.Name: NA
PE.Description: Note displaying the woman's average weekly weight gain since last contact and woman's total weight gain so far in this pregnancy (both in kg).

PE.Label: Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) risk counseling
PE.Info icon:
Please provide appropriate counseling for GDM risk mitigation, including: 
- Reasserting dietary interventions
- Reasserting physical activity during pregnancy
PE.Name: NA
PE.Description: Note displaying that the woman is at risk of developing pre-eclampsia. Counseling, aspirin (after 12 weeks) and calcium supplementation (if is low intake in area) are recommended.

PE.Label: Healthy eating and keeping physically active counseling
PE.Info icon:
Healthy eating and keeping physically active during pregnancy is recommended for pregnant women to stay healthy and to prevent excessive weight gain during pregnancy.

[Nutritional and Exercise Folder]
PE.Name: NA
PE.Description: Counseling on healthy eating and keeping physically active during pregnancy.

PE.Label: Increase daily energy and protein intake counseling
PE.Info icon:
Increase daily energy and protein intake to reduce the risk of low-birth-weight neonates.

[Protein and Energy Sources Folder]
PE.Name: NA
PE.Description: Note displaying that counseling on increasing daily energy and protein intake should be given.

PE.Label: Balanced energy and protein dietary supplementation counseling
PE.Info icon: Balanced energy and protein dietary supplementation is recommended for pregnant women to reduce the risk of stillbirths and small-for-gestational-age neonates.
PE.Name: NA
PE.Description: Note displaying that counseling on balanced energy and protein dietary supplementation should be given.

PE.Label: Any symptoms of severe pre-eclampsia?
PE.Name: symp_sev_preeclampsia
PE.Description: Check if the woman has any of the following symptoms of severe pre-eclampsia.
PE.Constraint(s): "None" cannot be selected with any other symptom.

PE.Label: Urine dipstick result - protein
PE.Name: urine_protein
PE.Description: Enter the result for the dipstick test - protein.
PE.Default?: Populate result from "Tests" tab if not blank.

PE.Label: NA
PE.Name: hypertension
PE.Description: The woman is considered hypertensive if she has an elevated BP but a normal urine dipstick protein test result (none or +).

PE.Label: Hypertension diagnosis! Provide counseling.
PE.Info icon:
Woman has hypertension - SBP of 140 mmHg or higher and/or DBP of 90 mmHg or higher and no proteinuria.

Counseling:
- Advice to reduce workload and to rest
- Advise on danger signs
- Reassess at the next contact or in 1 week if 8 months pregnant
- If hypertension persists after 1 week or at next contact, refer to hospital or discuss case with the doctor, if available
PE.Name: NA
PE.Description: Note displaying that the woman has been diagnosed with hypertension (SBP of 140 mmHg or higher and/or DBP of 90 mmHg or higher and no proteinuria) and should be counseled.

PE.Label: NA
PE.Name: severe_hypertension
PE.Description: The woman is considered to have severe hypertension if she has SBP of 160 mmHg or above and/or DBP of 110 mmHg or above.

PE.Label: Severe hypertension! Refer urgently to hospital!
PE.Info icon: Woman has severe hypertension. If SBP is 160 mmHg or higher and/or DBP is 110 mmHg or higher, then refer urgently to the hospital for further investigation and management.
PE.Name: NA
PE.Description: Note displaying that the woman has hypertension and her BP is too high (160 mmHg or higher and/or DBP is 110 mmHg or higher) and must be referred.

PE.Label: Symptom(s) of severe pre-eclampsia! Refer urgently to hospital!
PE.Info icon: Woman has hypertension. If she is experiencing a symptom of severe pre-eclampsia, then refer urgently to the hospital for further investigation and management.
PE.Relevance: {hypertension} = 1 AND selected({symp_sev_preeclampsia}, "Severe headache" OR "Blurred vision" OR "Epigastric pain" OR "Dizziness" OR "Vomiting")
PE.Name: NA
PE.Description: Note displaying that the woman has hypertension and is experiencing a symptom of severe pre-eclampsia (severe headache or blurred vision or epigastric pain or dizziness or vomiting) and must be referred.

PE.Label: NA
PE.Name: severe_preeclampsia
PE.Description: The woman is considered to have severe pre-eclampsia if she has SBP of 160 mmHg or above and/or DBP of 110 mmHg or above and proteinuria 3+ OR woman has SBP of 140 mmHg or above and/or DBP of 90 mmHg or above and proteinuria 2+ with at least one symptom of severe pre-eclampsia.
PE.Calculation: if((({bp_systolic_repeat} >= 160 OR {bp_diastolic_repeat} >= 110) AND {urine_protein} = "+++" or "++++") OR (({urine_protein} = "++" or "+++" or "++++") AND ({symp_sev_preeclampsia} = "Severe headache" OR "Blurred vision" OR "Epigastric pain" OR "Dizziness" OR "Vomiting"), 1, 0)

PE.Label: Severe pre-eclampsia diagnosis! Provide urgent treatment and refer to hospital!
PE.Info icon:
Woman has severe pre-eclampsia - SBP of 160 mmHg or above and/or DBP of 110 mmHg or above and proteinuria 3+ OR woman has SBP of 140 mmHg or above and/or DBP of 90 mmHg or above and proteinuria 2+ with at least one symptom of severe pre-eclampsia.

Procedure:
- Give magnesium sulphate
- Give appropriate anti-hypertensives 
- Revise the birth plan 
- Refer urgently to hospital!
PE.Name: NA
PE.Description: Note displaying that the woman has severe pre-eclampsia (SBP of 160 mmHg or above and/or DBP of 110 mmHg or above and proteinuria 3+ OR woman has SBP of 140 mmHg or above and/or DBP of 90 mmHg or above and proteinuria 2+ with at least one symptom of severe pre-eclampsia) and must be treated and referred.

PE.Label: NA
PE.Name: preeclampsia
PE.Description: The woman is considered to have preeclampsia if she has SBP of 140 mmHg or above and/or DBP of 90 mmHg or above and proteinuria 2+ and no symptom of severe pre-eclampsia.
PE.Calculation: if(({urine_protein} = "++" or "+++" or "++++") AND {symp_sev_preeclampsia} = "None" AND ({bp_systolic_repeat} < 160 and {bp_diastolic_repeat} < 110)), 1, 0)

PE.Label: Pre-eclampsia diagnosis! Refer to hospital and revise birth plan.
PE.Info icon:
Woman has pre-eclampsia - SBP of 140 mmHg or above and/or DBP of 90 mmHg or above and proteinuria 2+ and no symptom of severe pre-eclampsia.

Procedure: 
- Refer to hospital 
- Revise the birth plan
PE.Name: NA
PE.Description: Note displaying that the woman has preeclampsia (SBP of 140 mmHg or above and/or DBP of 90 mmHg or above and proteinuria 2+ and no symptom of severe pre-eclampsia) and must be referred.

PE.Description: The woman's body temperature in degrees Celsius.

PE.Label: Woman has a fever. Provide treatment and refer urgently to hospital!
PE.Info icon:
Procedure:
- Insert an IV line
- Give fluids slowly
- Refer urgently to hospital!
PE.Name: NA

Tests.Description: In addition to the rapid on-site syphilis test, if the setting does not have a low coverage of syphilis screening and treatment for pregnant women or if the syphilis prevalence is low (< 5%), then off-site lab screening testing for syphilis can be done instead of the rapid on-site syphilis test.

Tests.Label: Urine test
Tests.Info icon: A urine test is required at the first contact, last contact in 2nd trimester, and 2nd contact in 3rd trimester OR anytime the woman reports pain during urination (dysuria). A dipstick test is required if the woman has a repeat high BP reading (140/90 or higher). Otherwise, a urine test is optional. The urine test checks for bacterial or other infections that can lead to adverse outcomes for the neonate. The urine dipstick test can check for proteins in the urine, which can be a sign of pre-eclampsia.
Tests.Due: (First contact AND Last contact in 2nd trimester AND 2nd contact in 3rd trimester) OR selected({other_sym_lbpp}, "Pain during urination (Dysuria)")
Tests.Name: urine_test_status
Tests.Description: A urine test is required at the first contact, last contact in 2nd trimester, and 2nd contact in 3rd trimester OR anytime the woman reports pain during urination (dysuria). A dipstick test is required if the woman has a repeat high BP reading (140/90 or higher). Otherwise, a urine test is optional. The urine test checks for bacterial or other infections that can lead to adverse outcomes for the neonate. The urine dipstick test can check for proteins in the urine, which can be a sign of preeclampsia.

Tests.Label: NA
Tests.Name: gdm_risk
Tests.Description:
The woman is considered at risk for GDM if she has any of the following risk factors: 
- BMI of 30 kg/m2 or more
- Previous GDM
- Previous macrosomia 
- Glycosuria on dipstick testing is ++ or above on one occasion OR + on two or more occasions)
Tests.Calculation: if(({bmi} >= 30) OR ({prev_preg_comps} = 'Gestational Diabetes' or 'Macrosomia') OR ({urine_glucose} = '++', '+++', or '++++') OR ({urine_glucose} = '+' more than once), 1, 0)
Tests.OpenMRS entity: Concept - At risk for gestational diabetes

Tests.Label: Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) risk counseling
Tests.Info icon:
Please provide appropriate counseling for GDM risk mitigation, including: 
- Reasserting dietary interventions
- Reasserting physical activity during pregnancy
Tests.Name: NA
Tests.Description: Note displaying that the woman is at risk of developing gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) and counseling should be given to provide prevention options.

Tests.Label: NA
Tests.Name: asb_positive
Tests.Description:
A woman is considered to have ASB if she has one of the following test results:
- Positive culture (> 100,000 bacteria/mL)
- Gram-staining positive
- Urine dipstick test positive (nitrites or leukocytes)
Tests.Calculation: if({urine_culture} = "Positive - any agent" OR {urine_culture} = "Positive - Group B Streptococcus (GBS)" OR {urine_gram_stain} = "Positive" OR ({urine_nitrites} = "+" OR "++" OR "+++" OR "++++") OR ({urine_leukocytes} = "+" OR "++" OR "+++" OR "++++"), 1, 0)

Tests.Label: Seven-day antibiotic regimen for asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB)
Tests.Info icon:
A woman is considered to have ASB if she has one of the following test results:

- Positive culture (> 100,000 bacteria/mL)
- Gram-staining positive
- Urine dipstick test positive (nitrites or leukocytes)

Seven-day antibiotic regimen is recommended for all pregnant women with asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB) to prevent persistent bacteriuria, preterm birth and low birth weight.
Tests.Name: asb_positive_note
Tests.Description: Note displaying that woman has tested positive for ASB and seven-day antibiotic regimen is recommended.

Tests.Label: Intrapartum antibiotic to prevent early neonatal Group B Streptococcus (GBS) infection counseling
Tests.Info icon: Pregnant women with Group B Streptococcus (GBS) colonization should receive intrapartum antibiotic administration to prevent early neonatal GBS infection.

Tests.Description: Note displaying that woman should be given intrapartum antibiotic to prevent early neonatal Group B Streptococcus infection.

Tests.Label: NA
Tests.Name: gdm
Tests.Description:
The woman has Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (GDM) if her fasting plasma glucose is 92–125 mg/dL.

OR 

- 75g OGTT - fasting glucose 92–125 mg/dL
- 75g OGTT - 1 hr 180–199 mg/dL
- 75g OGTT - 2 hrs 153–199 mg/dL
Tests.Calculation: if(({fasting_plasma_gluc} >= 92 and < 126) OR ({ogtt_fasting} >= 92 and < 126) OR ({ogtt_1} >= 180 and < 200) OR ({ogtt_2} >= 153 and < 200), 1, 0)

- 75g OGTT - 2 hrs 200 mg/dL or higher

C&T.Label: BEHAVIOUR COUNSELING
C&T.Info icon: "BEHAVIOUR COUNSEL" for short

C&T.Label: Caffeine reduction counseling
C&T.Info icon:
Lowering daily caffeine intake during pregnancy is recommended to reduce the risk of pregnancy loss and low-birth-weight neonates.

This includes any product, beverage or food containing caffeine (e.g. brewed coffee, tea, cola-type soft drinks, caffeinated energy drinks, chocolate, caffeine tablets). Caffeine-containing teas (black tea and green tea) and soft drinks (colas and iced tea) usually contain less than 50 mg per 250 ml serving.
C&T.Relevance:
(caffeine_intake} = More than 2 cups (200ml) of filtered or commercially brewed coffee; More than 2 small cups (50 ml) of espresso; More than 3 cups (300ml) of instant coffee; More than 48 pieces (squares) of chocolate

OR

{behaviour_persist} = "High caffeine intake"
C&T.Name: caffeine_counsel
C&T.Description: Whether or not counselling was done on lowering daily caffeine intake.

C&T.Info icon: Ginger, chamomile, vitamin B6 and/or acupuncture are recommended for the relief of nausea in early pregnancy, based on a woman’s preferences and available options. Women should be informed that symptoms of nausea and vomiting usually resolve in the second half of pregnancy.

C&T.Label: Pharmacological treatments for nausea and vomiting counseling
C&T.Info icon: Pharmacological treatments for nausea and vomiting, such as doxylamine and metoclopramide, should be reserved for those pregnant women experiencing distressing symptoms that are not relieved by non-pharmacological options, under the supervision of a medical doctor.

C&T.Label: Hypertension counseling
C&T.Info icon:
Counseling:
- Advice to reduce workload and to rest
- Advise on danger signs
- Reassess at the next contact or in 1 week if 8 months pregnant
- If hypertension persists after 1 week or at next contact, refer to hospital or discuss case with the doctor, if available
C&T.Name: hypertension_counsel

C&T.Label: HIV positive counseling
C&T.Info icon:
Counseling:
- Refer to HIV services 
- Advise on opportunistic infections and need to seek medical help
- Proceed with systematic screening for active TB
C&T.Name: hiv_positive_counsel

C&T.Label: Hepatitis B positive counseling
C&T.Info icon:
Counseling:
- Provide post-testing counselling
- Request confirmatory Nucleic Acid Testing (NAT)
- Refer to hospital
C&T.Name: hepb_positive_counsel

C&T.Label: Hepatitis C positive counseling
C&T.Info icon:
Counseling:
- Provide post-testing counselling
- Request confirmatory Nucleic Acid Testing (NAT)
- Refer to hospital
C&T.Name: hepc_positive_counsel

C&T.Label: Syphilis counselling and treatment
C&T.Info icon:
Procedure:
- If primary or secondary stage of syphilis, please give single dose of benzathine penicillin 2.400.000 IU
- If late or unknown stage of syphilis, please give one dose of benzathine penicillin 2.400.000 IU weekly for 3 consecutive weeks
- Advise on treating her partner
- Encourage HIV testing and counselling
- Reinforce use of condoms
C&T.Name: syphilis_low_prev_counsel

C&T.Label: Syphilis counselling and further testing
C&T.Info icon:
Procedure:
- If primary or secondary stage of syphilis, please give single dose of benzathine penicillin 2.400.000 IU
- If late or unknown stage of syphilis, please give one dose of benzathine penicillin 2.400.000 IU weekly for 3 consecutive weeks
- Advise on treating her partner
- Encourage HIV testing and counselling
- Reinforce use of condoms
- Proceed to further testing with an RPR test
C&T.Name: syphilis_high_prev_counsel

C&T.Label: NA
C&T.Name: penicillin
C&T.Description: Calculated field for woman's medications (penicillin).

C&T.Label: Seven-day antibiotic regimen for asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB)
C&T.Info icon: A seven-day antibiotic regimen is recommended for all pregnant women with asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB) to prevent persistent bacteriuria, preterm birth and low birth weight neonates.

C&T.Label: Diabetes counseling
C&T.Info icon:
Reassert dietary intervention and refer to high level care.

[Nutritional and Exercise Folder]
C&T.Name: diabetes_counsel

C&T.Label: Prescribe daily dose of 120 mg iron and 2.8 mg folic acid
C&T.Info icon:
If a woman is diagnosed with anaemia during pregnancy, her daily elemental iron should be increased to 120 mg until her haemoglobin (Hb) concentration rises to normal (Hb 110 g/L or higher). Thereafter, she can resume the standard daily antenatal iron dose to prevent re-occurrence of anaemia.

The equivalent of 120 mg of elemental iron equals 600 mg of ferrous sulfate heptahydrate, 360 mg of ferrous fumarate, or 1000 mg of ferrous gluconate.

[Iron sources folder]
C&T.Due: Every contact if relevant, until done

C&T.Label: HIV risk counseling
C&T.Info icon:
Provide comprehensive HIV prevention options: 
- STI screening and treatment (syndromic and syphilis)
- Condom promotion
- Risk reduction counselling
- PrEP with emphasis on adherence
- Emphasize importance of follow-up ANC contact visits
C&T.Name: hiv_risk_counsel

C&T.Label: PrEP for HIV prevention counseling
C&T.Info icon:
Oral pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) containing tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (TDF) should be offered as an additional prevention choice for pregnant women at substantial risk of HIV infection as part of combination prevention approaches.

[PrEP offering framework]

C&T.Description: Please explain why woman was not provided treatment.

C&T.Description: Specify any other reason why the treatment was not prescribed.

C&T.Label: Partner HIV test recommended
C&T.Info icon: Encourage woman to find out the status of her partner(s) or to bring them during the next contact visit to get tested.
C&T.Name: NA

C&T.Label: NA
C&T.Name: prep
C&T.Description: Calculated field for woman's medications (HIV PrEP).

C&T.Label: Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) risk counseling
C&T.Info icon:
Please provide appropriate counseling for GDM risk mitigation, including: 
- Reasserting dietary interventions
- Reasserting physical activity during pregnancy
C&T.Name: gdm_risk_counsel

C&T.Label: Seeking care for danger signs counseling
C&T.Info icon:
Danger signs include: 
- Headache
- No fetal movement
- Contractions
- Abnormal vaginal discharge
- Fever
- Abdominal pain
- Feels ill
- Swollen fingers, face or legs
C&T.Name: danger_signs_counsel
C&T.OpenMRS entity parent: Antenatal counseling, visiting hospital in presence of danger signs

C&T.Label: Counseling on going immediately to the hospital if severe danger signs
C&T.Info icon:
Severe danger signs include:
- Vaginal bleeding
- Convulsions/fits
- Severe headaches with blurred vision
- Fever and too weak to get out of bed
- Severe abdominal pain
- Fast or difficult breathing
C&T.Name: emergency_hosp_counsel
C&T.OpenMRS entity parent: Antenatal counseling, visiting hospital in presence of danger signs

C&T.Label: ANC contact schedule counseling
C&T.Info icon: It is recommended that a woman sees a healthcare provider 8 times during pregnancy (this can change if the woman has any complications). This schedule shows when the woman should come in to be able to access all the important care and information.
C&T.Name: anc_contact_counsel

C&T.Label: Woman should plan to give birth at a facility due to risk factors
C&T.Info icon:
Risk factors necessitating a facility birth:
- Age 17 or under
- Primigravida
- Parity 6 or higher
- Prior C-section
- Previous pregnancy complications: Heavy bleeding, Forceps or vacuum delivery, Convulsions, or 3rd degree tear
- Vaginal bleeding
- Multiple fetuses
- Abnormal fetal presentation
- HIV+
- Wants IUD or tubal ligation following delivery
C&T.Relevance: ({age} <= 17) OR ({fetal_presentation} = "Transverse" OR "Other") OR ({c_sections} > 0) OR ({no_of_fetuses} > 1) OR ({family_planning_type} = "IUD" OR "Tubal ligation") OR ({prev_preg_comps} = "3rd degree tear" OR "Heavy bleeding (during or after delivery)" OR "Forceps or vacuum delivery" OR "Convulsions") OR ({other_symptoms} = "Vaginal bleeding") OR ({gravida} = 1) OR ({parity} > 5) OR ({hiv_positive} = 1)
C&T.Name: NA

C&T.Label: Planned birth place
C&T.Name: delivery_place
C&T.OpenMRS entity parent: Birth plan, planned location of delivery

C&T.Label: Birth preparedness and complications readiness counseling
C&T.Info icon:
This includes: 
- Skilled birth attendant
- Labour and birth companion
- Location of the closest facility for birth and in case of complications
- Funds for any expenses related to birth and in case of complications
- Supplies and materials necessary to bring to the facility
- Support to look after the home and other children while she's away
- Transport to a facility for birth or in case of a complication 
- Identification of compatible blood donors in case of complications
C&T.Name: birth_prep_counsel

C&T.Label: Rh factor negative counseling
C&T.Info icon:
Counseling:
- Woman is at risk of alloimmunisation if the baby's father is Rh positive or unknown
- Proceed with local protocol to investigate sensitization and the need for referral 
- If non-sensitized, woman should receive anti-D prophylaxis postnatally if the baby is Rh positive
C&T.Name: rh_negative_counsel

C&T.Label: Intrapartum antibiotic to prevent early neonatal Group B Streptococcus (GBS) infection counseling
C&T.Info icon: Pregnant women with GBS colonization should receive intrapartum antibiotic administration to prevent early neonatal GBS infection.
C&T.Name: gbs_agent_counsel

C&T.Label: Breastfeeding counseling
C&T.Info icon:
To enable mothers to establish and sustain exclusive breastfeeding for 6 months, WHO and UNICEF recommend:

- Initiation of breastfeeding within the first hour of life
- Exclusive breastfeeding – that is the infant only receives breast milk without any additional food or drink, not even water
- Breastfeeding on demand – that is as often as the child wants, day and night
- No use of bottles, teats or pacifiers
C&T.Name: breastfeed_counsel

C&T.Label: Clinical enquiry for intimate partner violence (IPV) done?
C&T.Name: ipv_enquiry

C&T.Label: If the woman presents with risk of intimate partner violence (IPV), refer for assessment.
C&T.Name: ipv_refer

C&T.Label: Prescribe daily dose of 60 mg iron and 0.4 mg folic acid
C&T.Info icon:
Due to the population's high anaemia prevalence, a daily dose of 60 mg of elemental iron is preferred over a lower dose. A daily dose of 400 mcg (0.4 mg) folic acid is also recommended.

The equivalent of 60 mg of elemental iron is 300 mg of ferrous sulfate heptahydrate, 180 mg of ferrous fumarate, or 500 mg of ferrous gluconate.

[Iron sources folder]

C&T.Label: Prescribe daily dose of 30 to 60 mg iron and 0.4 mg folic acid
C&T.Info icon:
Daily oral iron and folic acid supplementation with 30 mg to 60 mg of elemental iron and 400 mcg (0.4 mg) of folic acid is recommended to prevent maternal anaemia, puerperal sepsis, low birth weight, and preterm birth.

The equivalent of 60 mg of elemental iron is 300 mg of ferrous sulfate heptahydrate, 180 mg of ferrous fumarate, or 500 mg of ferrous gluconate.

If daily iron is not acceptable due to side effects, provide intermittent iron and folic acid supplementation instead (120 mg of elemental iron and 2.8 mg of folic acid once weekly).

The equivalent of 120 mg of elemental iron equals 600 mg of ferrous sulfate heptahydrate, 360 mg of ferrous fumarate, or 1000 mg of ferrous gluconate.

C&T.Label: IPTp-SP dose 1
C&T.Info icon: Intermittent preventive treatment in pregnancy of malaria with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine (IPTp-SP) is recommended in malaria endemic areas. Doses should be given at least one month apart, starting in the 2nd trimester, with the objective of ensuring that at least three doses are received.
C&T.Name: iptp_sp1

C&T.Label: IPTp-SP dose 2
C&T.Info icon: Intermittent preventive treatment in pregnancy of malaria with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine (IPTp-SP) is recommended in malaria endemic areas. Doses should be given at least one month apart, starting in the 2nd trimester, with the objective of ensuring that at least three doses are received.
C&T.Name: iptp_sp2

C&T.Label: IPTp-SP dose 3
C&T.Info icon: Intermittent preventive treatment in pregnancy of malaria with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine (IPTp-SP) is recommended in malaria endemic areas. Doses should be given at least one month apart, starting in the 2nd trimester, with the objective of ensuring that at least three doses are received.

C&T.Info icon: Women who are taking co-trimoxazole SHOULD NOT receive IPTp-SP. Taking both co-trimoxazole and IPTp-SP together can enhance side effects, especially hematological side effects such as anaemia.

C&T.Label: TT dose #1
C&T.Info icon:
Tetanus toxoid vaccination is recommended for all pregnant women who are not fully immunised against TT to prevent neonatal mortality from tetanus.

1-4 doses of TTCV in the past:
- 1 dose scheme: Woman should receive one dose of TTCV during each subsequent pregnancy to a total of five doses (five doses protects throughout the childbearing years).

TTCV not received or unknown:
- 3 doses scheme:
  - 2 doses, 1 month apart
  - 2nd dose at least 2 weeks before delivery
  - 3rd dose 5 months after 2nd dose
C&T.Relevance: {tt_immun_status} = "Unknown" OR "TTCV not received" OR "1-4 doses of TTCV in the past"

C&T.Label: Prescribe a daily dose of up to 10,000 IU vitamin A, or a weekly dose of up to 25,000 IU
C&T.Info icon:
Give a dose of up to 10,000 IU vitamin A per day, or a weekly dose of up to 25,000 IU.

A single dose of a vitamin A supplement greater than 25,000 IU is not recommended as its safety is uncertain. Furthermore, a single dose of a vitamin A supplement greater than 25,000 IU might be teratogenic if consumed between day 15 and day 60 from conception.

[Vitamin A sources folder]

C&T.Label:
Dietary supplements NOT recommended:
- High protein supplement 
- Zinc supplement
- Multiple micronutrient supplement
- Vitamin B6 supplement
- Vitamin C and E supplement
- Vitamin D supplement
C&T.Info icon:
Vitamin B6: Moderate certainty evidence shows that vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) probably provides some relief for nausea during pregnancy.

Vitamin C: Vitamin C is important for improving the bioavailability of oral iron. Low-certainty evidence on vitamin C alone suggests that it may prevent pre-labour rupture of membranes (PROM). However, it is relatively easy to consume sufficient quantities of vitamin C from food sources. 

[Vitamin C folder]

Vitamin D: Pregnant women should be advised that sunlight is the most important source of vitamin D. For pregnant women with documented vitamin D deficiency, vitamin D supplements may be given at the current recommended nutrient intake (RNI) of 200 IU (5 μg) per day.
C&T.Name: NA
C&T.Description: Dietary supplements that are not recommended

Pop Charact..Label: Undernourished prevalence 20% or higher
Pop Charact..Name: pop_undernourish
Pop Charact..Info icon: The proportion of women in the adult population (18 years or older), with a BMI less than 18.5, is 20% or higher.

Pop Charact..Label: Anaemia prevalence 40% or higher
Pop Charact..Name: pop_anaemia_40
Pop Charact..Info icon: The proportion of pregnant women in the population with anaemia (haemoglobin level less than 11 g/dl) is 40% or higher.

Pop Charact..Label: Anaemia prevalence 20% or lower
Pop Charact..Name: pop_anaemia_20
Pop Charact..Info icon: The proportion of pregnant women in the population with anaemia (haemoglobin level less than 11 g/dl) is 20% or lower.

Pop Charact..Label: Low dietary calcium intake
Pop Charact..Name: pop_low_calcium
Pop Charact..Info icon: Women in the population are likely to have low dietary calcium intake (less than 900 mg of calcium per day).

Pop Charact..Label: TB prevalence 100/100,000 or higher
Pop Charact..Name: pop_tb
Pop Charact..Info icon: The tuberculosis prevalence in the general population is 100 cases per 100,000 persons or greater.

Pop Charact..Label: Vitamin A deficiency 5% or higher
Pop Charact..Name: pop_vita
Pop Charact..Info icon: The prevalence of night blindness is 5% or higher in pregnant women or 5% or higher in children 24–59 months of age, or the proportion of pregnant women with a serum retinol level less than 0.7 mol/L is 20% or higher.

Pop Charact..Label: Soil-transmitted helminth infection prevalence 20% or higher
Pop Charact..Name: pop_helminth
Pop Charact..Info icon: The percentage of individuals in the general population infected with at least one species of soil-transmitted helminth is 20% or higher.

Pop Charact..Label: HIV incidence greater than 3 per 100 person-years in the absence of PrEP
Pop Charact..Name: pop_hiv_incidence
Pop Charact..Info icon: Women in the population have a substantial risk of HIV infection. Substantial risk of HIV infection is provisionally defined as HIV incidence greater than 3 per 100 person–years in the absence of pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP).

Pop Charact..Label: HIV prevalence 5% or higher
Pop Charact..Name: pop_hiv_prevalence
Pop Charact..Info icon: The HIV prevalence in pregnant women in the population is 5% or higher.

Pop Charact..Label: Syphilis prevalence 5% or higher
Pop Charact..Name: pop_syphilis
Pop Charact..Info icon: The prevalence of syphilis in pregnant women in the population is 5% or higher.

Pop Charact..Label: Hep B prevalence is intermediate (2% or higher) or high (5% or higher)
Pop Charact..Name: pop_hepb
Pop Charact..Info icon: The proportion of Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) seroprevalance in the general population is 2% or higher.

Pop Charact..Label: National Hep B ANC routine screening program established
Pop Charact..Name: pop_hepb_screening
Pop Charact..Info icon: There is a national Hepatitis B ANC routine screening program in place.

Pop Charact..Label: Hep C prevalence is intermediate (2% or higher) or high (5% or higher)
Pop Charact..Name: pop_hepc
Pop Charact..Info icon: The proportion of Hepatitis C virus (HCV) antibody seroprevalence in the general population is 2% or higher.
